item.title: Brexit One Year Later: Markets Might Get It Wrong Again
item.description: The Brexit vote sank the pound but buoyed the FTSE 100. That relationship might be changing.

item.title: BlackBerry's Valuation Got Disconnected
item.description: BlackBerry’s share price surged in the months since it was awarded millions in an arbitration dispute with Qualcomm. Disappointing quarterly results wiped out a chunk of those gains.

item.title: For Consumers, Less Debt but Lots of Bills
item.description: As a group, U.S. households’ debt-to-income and debt-to-asset ratios in the first quarter fell to their lowest levels since the early 2000s. But financial obligations beyond debt payments, such as rents and auto leases, are taking a bigger bite out of pay.

item.title: Weibo Gets in Beijing's Way
item.description: Investors need to consider the political risk faced by China’s version of Twitter.

item.title: A New Risk for Goldman, Morgan Stanley in Stress Tests
item.description: This year’s bank stress tests turned up an unpleasant surprise for Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. The banks scored low on a metric introduced for the first time this year, the supplementary leverage ratio, meant to measure banks’ total leverage.

item.title: China's Debt Crackdown Could Get Out of Hand
item.description: High flying Anbang and HNA are the latest victims of a broad crackdown on risk in China. The well-worn thesis that China would have a boring year ahead of its leadership summit has proven false.

item.title: 'Immaterial' Revision or Not, Hain Still has Problems
item.description: An internal investigation at Hain Celestial Group found past errors in its accounting were immaterial. Investors care more about the company’s future, which still looks troubled

item.title: A Risky Bet By Investors---That the Health-Care Bill Fails
item.description: The Better Care Reconciliation Act of 2017 is here, and investors aren’t remotely concerned.

item.title: Uber: Too Big to Flail
item.description: The investors who have sunk many billions into Uber can take at least some comfort in the reality that scale still matters—by a lot.
